pros: Gaudenzia is on the Frontline of the addiction crisis facing our country. They provide care to people regardless of their ability to pay. cons: They don't value staff who work long hours there is no staff appreciation and no one cares if you quit. If they just took the time to appreciate staff there would be less turnover. They spend money on everything but staff.

review_title: High Turn Over, High Burn Out Rate
pros: There are some sincere staff who actually care about clients and try to help people along in their recovery.
cons: The ones who sit in high places don't seem to really care about staff and/or clients. The ones on the front lines in the programs start off as caring individuals but a couple years (or even months) in and they are burned out and not really effective at their jobs anymore. Some people in senior management just collect a paycheck and you're not exactly sure what they do... If you sincerely care about people who are struggling with addiction, you will be highly disappointed to see how these programs are run. Front line program staff are grossly... grossly underpaid while those in higher up positions are sitting pretty, riding around in their company-payed-for vehicles. Gaudenzia has the potential to offer quality programming but because of the chaotic, unprofessional, and demeaning way that it is run as a company, it is bad news. I would really not recommend any one work here let alone send any of their family members here for treatment. Please reconsider if you are looking at this place for either employment or treatment. It may have been good back in the early days, but now it is the pits. It's actually very sad.

pros: Helping addicts trying to recover
cons: Unqualified Management who treat clients & staff either horrific with disrespectful, condescending attitudes or unacceptably familiar & overtly manipulative (usually male mgt taking advantage of female addict during her most vulnerable time of detox, early stages of recovery. Counselors are responsible for almost every administrative function which takes significant time away from clients & promotes an unspoken culture of deception when fudging records to get insurance money or satisfy requirements for inspection & continued certification. Kitchen is clean but food is not - expired items line the shelves of the pantry - clients end up being served hot dogs due to Mgt's sticky fingers with the high quality food donations (seafood, steak, roasted chicken - all magically disappear before even get into facility. ..

job_title: Drug and Alcohol Counselor in Philadelphia, PA
pros: working with a diverse D/A inmate patient population. working with (few) colleagues that have or are working on acquiring their Bachelor's or Master's in counseling. The job skills training instructor (JE) was a joy to learn from.
cons: The pay is horrible for what you are expected to do. There is no shortage of groups, and little to no time to run them. Fast-paced environment with no clinical support. Clinical directors and supervisors in name only, as they have no credentials, i.e. MSW, LPC, LSW, LCSW, to supervise or run a human services dept. "Clinical supervisors" supervision consists of managing your productivity, and not assisting you with refining clinical skills, (see aforementioned point above). Most employees in the building after a month of hire appears on edge, ready to snap.

pros: A program team that was awesome
cons: To many to list here. If you value your integrity and ethical behavior - stay away from this organization. Lowest pay-scale in the industry and many of the formal authority are recovered addicts with NO business acumen. Most employess are disgruntled and also looking to leave. This is what happens when you make an intelligent human being into a ‘thing’ through the obsolete and ineffective practice of micro-management. Dis-empowering a person is at the heart of most organizational failures. This is the only model gaudenzia follows - reactive and micro-manage.

review_title: If you are thinking of working here run away. Run away as fast as you can!
pros: Medical Benefits are good for the price. You get 10 days off your first year and it increases every year until you reach 24 than it stops.
cons: You do not get promoted if you are good at what you are currently doing unless you kiss butt and are a "pet".  Salaries suck unless you are upper management. They do not care about you and your family. If you have a family emergency you are SOL. Management is very unorganized. There is poor communication. No one has a set schedule so having a much needed second job is next to impossible.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in West Chester, PA
pros: It's extremely hard to get fired. Appearantly you can keep you job when you violate the codes of ethics and conduct when your in a management postion.
cons: All staff does is gossip. The staff talk to the clients with such disrespect. Horribly micromanaged. Over worked with terrible pay. They will make you salary so they don't have to pay you overtime. The benefits are terrible for the deductible you pay.  You are intimidated by upper management staff on a daily basis and embarrassed by them also in front of other staff  and clients.

pros: I enjoyed my job as being an assessor for the only 24-hr assessment site in Bucks County. I was passionate about placing people seeking help in an appropriate level of care and then quickly finding them adequate treatment options. I enjoyed the clientele and was motivated by the quick-paced environment.
cons: The reason why I left Gaudenzia was that I felt misled by upper management about benefits. I was hired as a "part-time" employee, with the promise that I would be considered full-time "soon." I was reassured that while they didn't have a full-time "role" available for me, that I would be scheduled full-time hours and would be considered full-time imminently. I worked there for 9 months, and was never ONCE scheduled less that 40 hours a week. I often worked over-time. This was not a huge issue, but I was an overnight assessor (a largely undesirable shift) and was consistently being given the run-around about benefits. Just in case you might view me as a disgruntled employee bad-mouthing a former employer, rest assured that I liked many aspects of my job and was willing to wait for these benefits. The sad part is, they never came and once I put in my notice and informed upper management of why I was in fact leaving, I was ignored and never reassured that the benefits were, in fact, coming. I felt disregarded as an employee, despite being told during all supervisions with my superiors how valuable they found me to be. This complaint has been lodged with HR during my exit interview.  Like many treatment facilities, the Lower Bucks location is highly understaffed and there is a lack of security guards, which was unsafe considering the high amount of overdoses and illegal activity occurring on the property while people would await bed placement.

review_title: One of the best and worst experiences of my life
pros: The clients and doing something that matters.  There is growth opportunity but only because the high turnover!  It is a company that does not flip out on you or you have to worry about your job if you make a mistake! Mistakes are allowed
cons: Unreasonable workload that cannot be met no overtime allowed I are always stressed and set up for failure.  The staff in recovery get to do whatever they want and the ones who aren't are heals to a different standard

review_title: our company sub-contracts out to prison services.I feel that our substance abuse program is essential to prison services

cons: i drive 64 miles round trip every day m-f and would like employment in my chosen field closer to home

pros: All inclusive place for those in recovery and are committed to their recovery.  Educational opportunities are great. Adequate benefit package.
cons: Pay does not reflect prior experience. It took a long time to start causing financial hardship.  Unprofessional staff towards client's. First floor could be managed better if supervised by a guard.

review_title: This is a female dominated company that does not like for guys that's not their friend to get promoted.

cons: No men without any friends in the company will ever go anywhere. The company is about 85% women that are friends.

pros: You get annual and promotional raises, worked with good counselors, gain a lot of experience with SA/MH, adolescents, groups, criminal justice system. This job makes you very marketable
cons: too much paper work, unrealistic expectations of getting paperwork done, not enough time to complete paper work, no security, very unorganized, very fast pace, lack of communication

pros: Great place to work. My team was very cohesive and we had the bigger picture in mind when we had things to get done. I had a wonderful boss that raised me up to challenge my abilities and do a better job.
cons: It was difficult to have people buy into our policies and procedures for reporting maintenance issues. We were always putting fires out instead having the issue in our system to address them with due diligence.

review_title: worse than the clients they serve
job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse III in Shiremanstown, PA
pros: decent benefits for the price - decent vacation
cons:
Ethical violations abound through out organization- overworked and underpaid - won't pay overtime - but will not give time to complete work either - ask staff to work off the clock even after fined by the state for behavior - If you are seeking recovery - this is not the place to do it 
Ethics with staff involved with clients - during and after treatment - this is where to go if you want to learn how not to live your life after addiction

review_title: Ability to help others with addiction

pros: There was a lot of room to use your creativity and knowledge. Was able to incorporate what I thought was relevant into the curriculum.

pros: Loved helping individuals who struggled with drugs and alcohol and gave peer to peer feedback. Enjoyed sharing my experience, strength, and hope with clients

pros: Watching those who actually get treatment in spite of the workload that keeps counselors away from clients
cons: Cult, poor pay for what is expected for the people who work, executives making big bucks, too many staff have gotten ill while trying to do their job, denial of compensation once you are made ill (you are replaceable), too many internal cliques in upper management (co-sign unethical behavior), buildings should be torn down instead of patched, female leaders running organization into the toilet.
